WRITING.TEXT: That sounds quite a moving idea for a poem. I think poems with a narrative are quite interesting. And yeah, writer's block can be really awful. Good luck with the poem!
I wonder if titles like that get a bit predictable after a while, though. I'm a bit put off of books starting with 'The Girl...' at this point, lol.
I don't read much poetry, but collections of poetry usually have really beautiful titles.
Yep, Japanese sentence endings are always beautiful. (desu) and (de gozaimasu) I like also.
Yes, I love colloquial. I remember when I was learning another language, I had to look up what it actually meant, lol. 'Colloquialism' is also good.

I definitely think there can be good one word titles, it just depends on what connotations the word has and what it evokes for the reader. I like the title 'Yellow' by Janni Visman, I find any title that has a colour in it evokes interest.

I think that's a good point, as well. The title is very much a part of the writer's vision. Often when I write, I try to make any titles inspiring to readers, since that's part of the technique I learnt when studying creative writing. I like to evoke the feel of the story, whilst trying to make it a bit intriguing for the reader.
I've definitely bought books based on cover art. In fact, the book I mentioned in my original post, 'Evening is the Whole Day', has one edition with a beautiful illustration of a flower on the cover, which was what made me choose it. The other edition's cover I didn't find particularly inspiring, so I might not even have picked it up. I am a bit fickle when it comes to book covers...
I think Blood Meridian is an amazing title. It definitely suggests the bloody, Western feel of the book. And Cormac McCarthy has one of the most amazing writing styles, as well.

Do you think the admin was serious?
On a side note, the real question the admin's comments raised to me is to what extent should STEM students give up their personal needs for the sake of scientific progress? In that admin's train of thought, a majority of people should be forced into STEM subjects and spend as much time as possible at their work for the sake of progress. In my view, people should be able to do what they want, rather than have to sacrifice for the 'greater good', as long as they take care of their personal responsibilities. Got a bit off-topic there, lol...
Definitely, the names of certain countries can be really beautiful. 'Mozambique' is probably my favourite.

Nordic languages are beautiful. I think there are some nice English words, but most are generally quite plain. I think American English can sometimes have nicer words than British English, like I prefer 'sidewalk' to 'pavement'.
I just heard of that word this week, and I liked it then. I actually experience this feeling quite a bit, so it was cool to know there's actually a word for it.
I'd never heard of that word before, but that's pretty hilarious it exists.

WRITING.TITLE: The importance of book titles
WRITING.TEXT:
I'm currently reading Alice Munro's short story collection, 'Dear Life'. I've enjoyed quite a few of the stories in the collection, but I think some of their names are a bit lackluster. One or two word titles like, 'Gravel' and 'Haven'. It didn't really give me any kind of idea of what the story might be like or get me interested in some of the themes or events that might be involved.
It got me thinking about the importance of titles for books and short stories. This might be something more important for short stories, because there's not always a lot of information about what each individual story is like on the back cover, so you only really have the titles on the contents page to go on.
A book title I absolutely love, and that made me want to pick the book out in the first place was, 'Evening is the Whole Day' by Preeta Samarasan. The contradictory statement and its implications of days filled with darkness was an image that really interested me from the outset. I believe it's actually a quote from a translation of a poem featured in Kuruntokai, a classical Tamil poetry anthology. This ties in with some of the book's themes of Indian migration to Malaysia, and is mentioned in the book. It's such an inspiring title.
How important do you think book and short story titles are? Have you ever bought a book based on the title? Do you have a favourite title?
I've had this on my bookshelf for years. I now suddenly really want to read it...

WRITING.TITLE: Favourite words?
WRITING.TEXT:
...Either because of the sound or their meaning, or another reason. Non-English words would obviously count also.
I love the sound of the words 'flotsam' and 'jetsam', and also 'ocean'. So, a lot of words related to the sea. 'Atmosphere' is also beautiful.
For its meaning, I love the word 'freedom'. I also love the word 'darou' or , a Japanese word roughly meaning 'probably'. I like the way the Japanese 'r' sound mixes into the lengthened 'oh' sound at the end.
Oh god, if I'd gone to a physical university it would have had to be Lincoln. Thank God for the Open University. I have been spared all of this crap!
Ace Attorney reddit is the best reddit.
Ah, I didn't know that. Good luck with the degree! :)
I think sometimes school can make English quite boring lol. Hope you get round to doing some writing in between all the coursework!

I think it makes it better, like I appreciate it on a different level. I'm not just enjoying reading, but mining for ideas. In a way, I prefer it when the book I study for coursework is one I don't like, because then it doesn't spoil it for me. XD
We have to write a Wikipedia-style article about conflict during the Industrial revolution, using specific sources. I took part in a similar activity earlier in the year which went well. I can be a bit of a control freak when it comes to coursework, so it was definitely a learning curve!

I wanted to go into video game translation at the time, so I thought it might be good if I had some coding experience. But C++ looked too intimidating for me, so I tried learning HTML to start. I enjoyed what I learned, but ended up going on to other things. I think I'm less good on the technical front, I tend to be better at creative things.
I've been trying to write a short story collection. It's very difficult without having a total understanding of how writing works, but I'm muddling through it. I'd recommend creative writing courses, but I think it can be done without them. There's a lot of helpful information I've read online, and reading books of course helps. I analyse pretty much everything from a writer's perspective, films, video games, works of art, real life conversations. It gets to the point where it's hard to switch off. XD
Wow, that's quite a lot to get through! My course is part time till next year, so I have a much lighter workload for now. I have some work on analysing sources to complete, but there's a couple of weeks left till my next assignment, which is a group project.

Yes, I was a freshman when I did that essay. I'm near the end of my second year now. I suspect the word count will go up, though strangely this year it seems to have gone down.
That's quite a complex subject, will it be your last essay, then?

Is it just the pronunciation you find difficult? I used to study Japanese, and I always found pronunciation the hardest. I wonder if there's anything on YouTube about French pronunciation that might be helpful?
My degree is English Literature and Creative Writing. Psychology is very interesting, if I hadn't gone with creative writing, it would probably have been my second choice.
International Relations, that sounds interesting, but certainly very challenging! Good luck with the 10k words, my longest assignment so far has only been 2k. What's the thesis on?

3D modelling and A.I both sound really interesting, but my nearest experience of coding is a bit of HTML I did years ago. I completely agree. I think university is more about the core skills it gives you, rather then just the qualification. University is great because it pushes you to create coherent work by yourself within a deadline, and I've noticed myself improve drastically as person since I started.
Yes, that was my problem with writing. I'd write heaps of notes and ideas, but when it came to actually writing something, it came out as an incoherent mess and I'd get fed up with it. My course forces me to write shorter, planned pieces, so I can really focus on the techniques I'm using. I also got feedback from other students on my writing, which is invaluable.
What is it you're working (or procrastinating) on now? Good luck with the course!

Good luck with the essay! Last year I got a nasty bout of flu and it pushed my assignment way back, and I got really stressed about it. Fortunately my tutor was very understanding and gave me an extension.
Wow, can you do both at the same time in Austria, then? (Excuse my ignorance)
I like meditation and things like that, so I think it's interesting things like grounding exercises are implemented in the classes. It sounds relaxing at least! What are you majoring in, by the way?

Exactly, I think IT is a very stable qualification, and it can be used to go into a variety of different fields. How far through it are you? I'm near the end of my second year (it's scary - I still feel like it's only just started!).
I've always wanted to be a writer, so when I saw the course, I knew I had to do it. I know it's not the most secure degree, but I suspect I'll go into something like communications anyway, and English is always useful for that. I've found the creative writing parts I've done so far absolutely brilliant, and I've been more confident in producing my own pieces of writing. If you're interested in writing, definitely keep it up, since it's a nice contrast to maths and IT.
I enjoy them, although it can get frustrating not being able to do the subject I chose right away. I can understand why the course is structured that way, since it's really about learning essay writing and primary/secondary sources, etc. I think doing subjects out of my comfort zone (I would never have considered studying R.E and classical studies) has pushed me further than ever before, so in that sense it has been very rewarding.

Maths is probably my worst subject -_-, but I do find IT interesting. Do you like it overall?
My degree is in English Literature and Creative Writing. We have to do two general arts courses before I start on my major, though, so I have to do a bit of stuff like history, philosophy, religious education, as well.
Wow, I've never heard of a class like that before. I like learning about managing groups and community building, but yeah, it sounds very 'hippy'-y. Do you like the class overall?
Is it a history teacher you want to be?
Is your French grade important for what you want to do?

Yes, I'm joking, if I'm honest I put it off a bit at the weekends! I try to do most of my coursework in the mornings. My problem tends to be poor planning, but I'm working on it. What course are you doing exactly?
Oh no, that sounds serious. XD
I'm the same with group tasks. I have to try not to take over, but I end up project managing it and contributing the most. Yay for being reliable!

Well, that's certainly one way of handling it lol!
I'm too much of a goody-two-shoes to put off my coursework and I still manage to be nearly late sending it in! XD

I felt this way a lot when I first started my degree. I think you can't predict what will happen, but if you're doing well right now, I think that's a pretty good sign. There's also usually lots of things universities have in place to support you if you're finding something difficult. I don't really believe in 'failure', I think if something goes wrong there are always ways around it or other options, and to me nothing in life is wasted.
It's maybe easy for me to say, but have faith in yourself. I think pretty much everyone feels like this sometime, and I'm sure that's not actually going to be the case. What degree is it you're doing?

Fortunately for me, my course is currently part-time (though it's full-time from next year) and I study from home, so I don't think I'm as swamped with coursework as some. With that being said, I've found as long as I structure my work time carefully and prioritize, I can keep on top of it quite easily. It's honestly not horrifically stressful like I thought it would be.

What's the paper about exactly?
I think the boring parts of study are the worst. Difficult essays with a deadline I'm fine with, but for me reading Hard Times was so boring, I found it one of the hardest parts to get through (the ending was good, though lol).
Oh, how I envy you! XD

Yeah, I try and stay ahead as much as possible. I start my work a week or so before the course starts, and try to keep things at that pace the whole way through. Though for my last assignment, I was about a couple of minutes off the deadline before submitting. So, my bad. -_-

WRITING.TITLE: Students of Reddit! How's the coursework going?
WRITING.TEXT: I'm doing an OU degree in English Literature and Creative Writing, and I've just had to read through Hard Times by Charles Dickens.

I suppose I used to be quite ageist, but I never expected to make friends with a much older person. One of my best friends is elderly and has Alzheimer's. Obviously she gets very confused sometimes, but she always remembers me, even if she doesn't know my name. Despite her difficulties she's one of the most considerate people I've ever met.
I also had a friend since childhood, I don't see her so much now, but we were polar opposites. She made me watch the Justin Bieber movie. Twice.
Beautiful! I love the use of colour and the girl's vivid staring eyes.

WRITING.TITLE: Anyone read this rather obscure book?
WRITING.TEXT: [removed]

Do you know exactly what's making you feel dissatisfied? Is there anything in particular you feel you want to do, but just aren't doing? I think if you want your life to be different, you should absolutely go for it. A couple of years ago I didn't do much socially, but I came out of my comfort zone and started volunteering, and it really opened things up for me.
Deadly Premonition is great. I think the glitches and the awkwardness adds to its charm. XD
I love the atmosphere in Dark Souls. Life is Strange is another favourite, too.
I like Fallout a lot, though I don't play many RPGs. Lots of people here seem to like Borderlands. I bought Borderlands 2 ages ago, so I should probably get round to actually playing it.

WRITING.TITLE: Favourite video games?
WRITING.TEXT: What kind of video games do you guys like? I'm mostly into mystery or horror games. Phoenix Wright, Hotel Dusk, Until Dawn and the Silent Hill franchise are probably my favorites.
I also have Liza Dalby's non-fiction books, 'Geisha' and 'Kimono', which I found really informative.
I loved this book as a teenager, since I was studying Japanese at the time.

I like the safety of living in a town, having lots of people nearby. But I'm in a flat right now, and really miss having a garden. Not having that connection to the outdoors makes me feel a bit cut off sometimes.
I love Varsity. I found them through browsing random music on YouTube. I get a Strokes vibe from their music.

'Teaching students to make socially aware games'
Aren't video games meant to be about having fun, not pushing political ideologies?

I love it! I think for me it's the movement in the flooring, it really draws the eye. And the slight tilt of the cabinets, and angles of the chairs. I almost feel like I'm about to walk into that cabin!

I don't have an Instagram right now, but I'm planning on getting one soon to put pictures of all my stuff on. I'd like to have an online shop at some point, too. What style of art do you like to draw in?
I love cats, so I'd hate to be allergic... :'(

I turn 20 in the next couple of weeks. Currently halfway through my degree in English Lit and Creative Writing. I make textile jewellery and constantly fail at writing short stories. I have a cat that snores very loudly.
Good luck with your degree. I'm pretty good at sorting out computers when there's a problem, but I'd be hopeless at degree level!

I like art and drawing, but I can't say I'm brilliant at it. I draw faces, but in kind of a semi-realistic style, onto felt, and use fabric to make hair, and then cut out the design to make into brooches.
I like bunnies, but I currently have a very lazy cat who snores a lot. Good luck with college and your degree in the arts. :)

I think the problem is the quality of the service depends on who you get. In my experience, the first person I saw was very by-the-book, and wanted to discharge me before I was actually better. The second person, however, was absolutely brilliant. She went absolutely out of her way to help me understand myself, and teach me techniques to manage my anxiety and OCD.
I'm not sure to what extent it's a gendered issue. I've only experienced it from a woman's perspective, and I am aware there are issues across the board with the mental health services (or at least in the UK). Some people just don't understand mental illness, even in the mental health services! With that being said, I do think it's harder for men to 'come out' about mental health, since they perhaps just keep going and don't discuss their issues. I have noticed a few men's support groups opening up here and there, so that's promising.
I myself am going through a bad patch with panic attacks, and they are difficult to deal with. Have you done any cognitive behavioural therapy, as the techniques there can be very helpful? My advice is to keep going out as much as you can, putting yourself into situations that set off your attacks, so you can see that nothing happens to you. I know how hard that is through first hand experience, but it's the only way it will get better. Panic attacks feel awful, but those feelings are essentially normal and can't actually hurt you. I really wish you good luck in dealing with your panic attacks.

Perhaps listen to a classical radio station. Since I was a kid my mum always had a classical music station on, and that was how I got to know all the pieces, and find new ones I like. I find I'm still learning now who the different composers are/were and which pieces are by who.
Perhaps also look into the specific genres or eras of classical music, and find the ones you like most. I personally enjoy piano and choral compositions the most, but there's plenty of other styles out there.

All of these composers are relatively modern - composing in the last twenty five to thirty years or so.
Ludovico Einaudi - I find his piano compositions the best. I Giorni was the piece of music that first got me hooked on classical music when I was 13. https://youtu.be/Uffjii1hXzU
Ryuuichi Sakamoto - Japanese film composer, very underrated https://youtu.be/LGs_vGt0MY8
Joe Hisaishi - Also a Japanese film composer, again very underrated, rarely hear him played on classical radio stations https://youtu.be/J7or0noYfMA
Sir Karl Jenkins - Everything he composes is amazing, and he works in a variety of classical genres, some of his music is choral, some tribal, some instrumental. The Benedictus makes me tear up a bit. https://youtu.be/zc1Zoz-NUro
Morten Lauridsen - His choral composition, 'O Magnum Mysterium' got me interested in choral music. https://youtu.be/Q7ch7uottHU

I love how they got such a 70s feel to the concert, really fits with the music. Watching performances from this concert on YouTube was the first time I was truly amazed by a live show. The Strokes are absolutely timeless.

The ending themes for 1 and 2 are absolutely breathtaking. They actually inspire me for making music outside the video game soundtrack genre. They're so nostalgic and moving. Whenever I listen to them, it's like I've gone back to when I was 12 and playing the series for the first time.
I remember, back before I twigged that YouTube existed, I used to replay to certain points in the game to hear my favourite pieces from the soundtrack. Just like the game itself, the music clings to you and never quite lets go.

I'm a newer fan, but I didn't like Comedown Machine at first because it's so different to their earlier style, but One Way Trigger, Happy Ending and Tap Out are some of my absolute favourite Strokes songs now. I think it's about enjoying it as work in and of itself and not comparing to their older style.
